report_text: **institution emergency department patient name: **name[aaa, bbb m] account #: **id-num date of service: **date[mar 01 06] primary care physician: **name[vvv m uuu] chief complaint: eye swelling. history of present illness: this is a **age[in 20s]-year-old african-american female with a history of sickle cell anemia who presents to the emergency department complaining of left eye swelling. she states she had a pimple near her left eye where she picked several days ago. she then began having some swelling and increased drainage from the site. the swelling progressed and over the weekend consumed her entire left eye. she states she is having central vision out of the left eye. her eye is swollen shut. she also states she has a headache. she denies any fevers or chills. she denies any cough or cold symptoms. she denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. she denies any nausea or vomiting or diarrhea. she states that even with her regular sickle cell regimen, pain medications are 1. morphine 60 mg p.o. t.i.d., as well as, 2. roxicet 5 mg p.r.n. she still is not getting relief from her pain. review of systems: negative except as listed in the hpi. past medical history: 1. sickle cell anemia. 2. vaginal herpes. 3. cholecystectomy. 4. left abdominal surgery. allergies: compazine which causes dyskinesia. medications: 1. folic acid. 2. zoloft. 3. vitamin. 4. percocet. 5. morphine. 6. penicillin. 7. stool softener. social history: the patient smokes about a half pack per day. she denies any other drug use. she does drink occasional alcohol, one or two drinks a month. physical exam: vital signs: temperature 36.8, pulse 64, respirations 16, blood pressure 108/60. in general, she is awake, alert, oriented, times three, and in no acute distress. heent exam reveals she has diffuse edema of the left eye. her eyelid is swollen. she has a small ulceration on her left temple with surrounding edema and erythema. there is no active drainage from the site. there is no fluctuant mass. cardiac: regular rate and rhythm. s1 and s2, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. the lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. abdomen is soft, nontender, nondistended. positive active bowel sounds are present. extremities: no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema. cbc was obtained which showed a white blood cell count of 15.2, h&h 11.3 and 32.5, platelets 176. a ct of the orbits were obtained which revealed left facial and preseptal periorbital inflammation consistent with cellulitis. her orbital contents and globes are intact. there are no bony lesion. there is some mild mucosal thickening of the inferior aspects of the maxillary sinuses. the remaining sinuses are clear. ed course: this is a **age[in 20s]-year-old with left eye cellulitis. ct was obtained to rule out eye involvement. per the ct there was no orbital content involvement. the patient did receive unasyn 3 gram iv while in the emergency department, as well as, dilaudid for pain control. due to the fact that there is no eye involvement, it was felt that the patient could be treated with p.o. antibiotics. the patient was discharged to home. she was given a prescription for bactrim ds b.i.d. to take for 10 days. she was told to follow up with her pcp tomorrow. she states she will call them tomorrow and be seen or return to the emergency department. the patient was understanding of all of the instructions and in agreement with the plan. the case was discussed with dr. **name[zzz] who is in full agreement with the plan. procedure(s): plan/follow-up: attending physician addendum: discharge
